subtitle: h Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. If you
watched yesterday's "In Presence" segment,
I talked about religion versus
spirituality. And the main point I made
at that time is that religious rituals
and prayers and blessings can become
mechanical with repetition. And when that
happens, you lose the spirit in which
these practices are supposed to be
engaged in. The Hebrew word for that is
kavanah - which I did a little research on
it since yesterday - literally it refers
to understanding the meaning of the
words, feeling the meaning of the words,
of the prayers, and blessings, and rituals
as you recite them. So often it just
becomes a question of "Can I say them
fast enough to get through them so I can
what eat the meal or do whatever comes
next?" We we don't really savor the moment.
Well, let me put it this way because
some people surely do savor the moment
in a religious context and that's where
religion and spirituality come together.
But in in my view, if you're repeating
the motions of the rituals, the prayers,
and the blessings without experiencing
the quality of that moment, the meaning
of the words as you say them, well then
you're losing touch with the
spirituality that's implied. Now, what I
really want to get at is an important
antidote to this kind of mechanical,
ritual religious practice is, in a word,
"novelty" - keeping things novel, doing
things in a new way, in a different way
each time. From a parapsychological point
of view, we find that that is very
important. When you keep the novelty of
your experiments high, people do better.
There's the beginner's luck effect, the
first time effect.
For example, one of the most successful
parapsychology researchers of all time
is Stephan Schwartz, who I've interviewed
any number of times - well to be specific
24 times - on the New Thinking Allowed
series. Now, Stephan is known or Stephan
I guess is the correct pronunciation of
his name spelled S-t-e-p-h-a-n. Anyhow, he's
known for his magnificent expeditions in
the field of applied parapsychology,
particularly archaeological expeditions.
Well, imagine how high the novelty is if
he takes you down in a submarine to do
remote viewing or brings you to Egypt to
go out into the middle of the Sahara
Desert and find buried villages under
the sands, or to find buried treasures in
the harbor of the city of Alexandria, the
ancient city. I think one of the reasons
Stephan has been so successful in these
expeditions is that each project is so
full of a novelty. In fact, I recall him
describing Hella Hammad, who has been a
great remote viewer, but she went down in
a submarine with him in one of these
expeditions he arranged for. It's
described in great detail in an earlier
episode of New Thinking Allowed, to which
I'm linking right now, if you look in the
upper right-hand portion of your screen,
you'll see it. But Hella was sick, she
was seasick, she was practically vomiting.
And yet her remote viewing work on that
occasion was it the same high standard
that she's always shown. So, that's one
example of how novelty is very important
in psychic work. Now some of you, I know,
leaned toward the conservative side in
your politics, and that may mean, I'll
tell you it's true of me in fact,
I often resist doing things in new and
different ways. My wonderful spouse,
Janelle, is always suggesting that I do
something new and different, and I can
feel that inner resistance each time,
like, "No, I like doing the things that I'm
comfortable with. I love my existing
habits. Why do I have to do something new
and different?" But it's good. It's healthy
to get outside your comfort zone. If all
you ever do is inside of your comfort
zone, if that's your issue as it is a bit
with me, then your life gets closed
in a bit. So, I'm very grateful for my
wife, even though I often resist her
suggestions at first. And then she finds
that funny. She gets a good chuckle
because she knows I'm going to come
around...eventually.
I want to give you another example of
the importance of novelty in
parapsychology, and that is the important
work being done by my friend Marty
Rosenblatt who runs an organization
called the Applied Precognition Project.
And what he has people doing, quite
specifically, is using remote viewing in
the area of financial forecasting and
sports wagering. And he's come up with
two important principles that have
enabled him to achieve, basically over a
decade period and hundreds of trials, a
sixty percent hit rate on these wagers
and speculations when you'd only expect
50 percent by chance. Now, the two
principles that he invokes to achieve
this success rate is: number one, don't
make large wagers or speculations so
that you get emotionally excited if you
win or emotionally dejected if your
trial is a failure. After all, if you have
a sixty percent hit rate, forty percent
of your trials will be failures and you
don't want to lose large amounts of money.
And if you make large amounts of money,
you run the risk of becoming what one
psychic once referred to as the goose
that laid the golden egg. And if that
goes to your head, again, the strong
emotions will interfere with psychic
functioning. But, the other key to the
successful work that Marty Rosenblatt
engages in is novelty. He is a group of, I
don't know, 200, 300 people working on
these applied-psi projects. But he
breaks them down into small groups, half
a dozen to a dozen people. In each of the
small groups, and they get to decide week-
by-week, what protocols they are going to
use. So, if they feel like changing the
protocol, which they often do because
they're very experimental, they're free
to do that.
He just keeps the statistics overall on
their hit rate. So, that kind of freedom
to constantly change things around is
very important. I did a another interview
with Charlie Tart, who's one of my
professors when I was a graduate student
in Parapsychology at Berkeley. And back
then, he had achieved a lot of prominence
with his work on learning to use ESP, but
the main point of that research which he
describes in another interview with me,
to which I am linking, is that if you
keep repeating the same kind of tests
over, and over, and over as the early
parapsychologists have done with their card
guessing experiments and computerized
ESP testing, you get what's known as a
decline effect which might be the same
thing as kind of the mechanical
repetition that occurs in religions when
you keep repeating the same ritual. Now,
let me conclude this monologue today
with just one story I got from my wife,
Janelle, who is a management consultant
trainer. And she's worked with a company
that has trained large corporations all
over the world.
And part of their training is
actually to encourage people to try
things in new ways. They say, for example,
wear your watch on the other hand, or if
you're entering your home, go in through
a different door, little things like that.
Get out of bed on the other side of your
bed. See what those changes will do for
your life. And they tell an interesting
story because on one occasion, a woman
raised her hand and a seminar and said,
"Well, what if you only have one door?" And
the fellow said, "Well go in through a
window." And she said, "Well what what if
you live on the second floor?" And the
fellow said, "Get a ladder." Of course he
was joking in in a way. But later on, this
same woman reported back to the company
and she said, "I tried what you suggested.
I went and I got a ladder, I had to climb
in through the second-story window of my
house."
She said, "About a half-hour later,
there was a knock on the door and when I
answered it (because this was in England)
it was a London Bobby who asked me, 'Is
everything okay?' I said, 'Yes of course. Why?'
And he said, 'Well, we
had a report somebody was breaking
into your apartment." And she said, "Oh no
that was just me. I was in a seminar. They
suggested I do things differently." And
the Bobby said, "Well, how interesting. You
know, I'm about to get off work. I'm about
to head over to the pub down the street.
Would you like to come and have a pint
with me?" And so she did. She was an
airline stewardess. She went and had a
beer with the Bobby who had knocked on
her door, and would you know it, several
months later, they got married.
So, that goes to show you what might
happen if you change some of your
routines and habits. I'll leave you to
ponder that thought. And once, again thank
you for being with me.
